summary: the genomes of all viruses in this superfamily are characterized by the presence of RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), chymotrypsin-like protease, superfamily 3 helicase (S3H) and genome-linked protein (26). among the families in this superfamily, Dicistroviridae and Picornaviridae are two families of positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses with similar gene contents but different genome organizations and hosts dogs are well-recognized reservoirs of viruses from at least seven families (42), including highly fatal viruses that can be transmitted to humans. no picornaviruses had been reported in dogs until 2011 (24, 36) RNA was extracted from nasopharyngeal swabs, fecal swabs, and urine. the RNA was eluted in 60 l of RNase-free water. RT-PCR of the 5′ UTR of picornaviruses was performed using conserved primers and DNA sequencing. for 1 min, 60°C for 1 min, 72°C for 1 min, and a final extension at 72°C for 10 min in an automated thermal cycler. the PCR products were subjected to gel purification using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (QIAgen, Hilden, Germany) the sequences of the PCR products were compared with known sequences of the 5′ UTR of picornaviruses. the 5′ ends of the viral genomes were confirmed by rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE) using a SMARTer RACE cDNA amplification kit (Clontech) the nucleotide sequences of the genomes and the deduced amino acid sequences were compared to those of other picornaviruses. a bicistronic plasmid was constructed on the backbone of pSP-FL+NF and pRL-CMV. firefly luciferase was used as the test reporter and Renilla luciferase as the control reporter. putative IRES sequences in the 5′ UTR (5′ IRES) and intergenic region (IGR IRES) were amplified. pRluc-IGR IRES-Fluc, intergenic region of CPDV inserted into pRluc-Fluc backbone. in vitro transcription of capped RNA was synthesized using a mMESSAGE mMACHINE kit. the pGL3-enhancer vector lacks a promoter but contains a simian virus 40 (SV40) enhancer located downstream of a firefly luciferase gene. plasmid-encoded Renilla luciferase was used as an internal control to normalize variations between transfection replicates. 1 g of pGL3-enhancer experimental plasmids was independently transfected into MDCK cells with 10 ng of Renilla luciferase reporter vector as a cotransfection control. cell lysates were incubated with firefly and Renilla luciferase-specific substrates following manufacturer's instructions. the reaction mixture was subjected to thermal cycling at 50°C for 2 min and 95°C for 10 min followed by 50 cycles of 95°C for 15 s and 55°C for 1 min. a 0.2-g volume of the amplicon was mixed with 2 l each of ATP, GTP, CTP, and UTP, 10 reaction buffer, and enzyme mix. a total of 368 dogs were captured from 38 different locations in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) during 22 months. RNA was extracted from nasopharyngeal swabs, fecal, urine, and blood samples. the RNA was eluted in 60 l of RNase-free water. the mixtures were amplified in 40 cycles of 94°C for 1 min, 60°C for 1 min, and 72°C for 1 min and a final extension at 72°C for 10 min. standard precautions were taken to avoid PCR contamination. the cDNA was converted to cDNA by a combined random-priming and oligo(dT) priming strategy. the 5′ ends of the viral genomes were confirmed by rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE) using a SMARTer RACE cDNA amplification kit (Clontech) the average evolutionary divergence for each coding region over the three strains of CPDV was estimated by the overall mean distance with p-distance method in MEGA 5 (50). a bicistronic Renilla/firefly dual-luciferase reporter plasmid was constructed on the backbone of pSP-FL+NF and pRL-CMV (Promega, Madison, WI) pRluc-Fluc, backbone and negative control; pRluc-HCV 5′ IRES-Fluc, positive control; pRluc-5′ IRES-Fluc, 5′ IRES of CPDV inserted into pRluc-Fluc backbone; pRluc-IGR IRES-Fluc, intergenic region of CPDV inserted into pRluc-Fluc backbone. the bicistronic construct containing encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) IRES was used as a positive control. each IRES element was excised from the bicistronic constructs. the pGL3-enhancer vector lacks a promoter but contains a simian virus 40 (SV40) enhancer. for each IRES construct, cells were transfected in triplicate in wells of a 12-well plate. for RNA transfection, cells were transfected in triplicate in wells of a 6-well plate. 1 g of pGL3-enhancer experimental plasmids was independently transfected into MDCK cells. quantitative RT-PCR was performed on 38 positive fecal and 9 positive urine samples. reaction mixture was subjected to thermal cycling at 50°C for 2 min and 95°C for 10 min followed by 50 cycles of 95°C for 15 s and 55°C for 1 min. the synthesized RNA was purified by lithium chloride precipitation. the concentration of purified RNA was quantified by UV light absorbance. the size of the purified RNA was assessed by running an aliquot of the purified RNA on an agarose gel. the genomes of all three strains of CPDV contain two putative IRES elements and two open reading frames (ORFs) there is 72% nucleotide identity between the 3′ 92 bases of 5′ UTR and the 3′ 89 bases of IGR (from position 3864 to 3952) IRES structures of the 5′ UTR (A) and the IGR (B) in CPDV are underlined. the P1 of CPDV possessed the highest amino acid identity (25.1%) to that of feline picornavirus (34). Y/N, presence of L but L is not protease; N, absence of L; Y, motif DDLXQ is present. 2A of CPDV possessed the highest amino acid identity (26.0%) to the recently discovered canine kobuvirus. 2C of CPDV possesses the DDLXQ motif for putative helicase activity (15) the P3 of CPDV possessed the highest amino acid identity (28.7%) to that of our recently discovered turdivirus 3 (55). 3Cpro of CPDV contains the conserved GXCG motif, which forms part of the substrate binding pocket of the protease (Table 3) (12). phylogenetic trees constructed using amino acid sequences of 3Dpol and 2C of CPDV and RdRp and S3H of other picornaviruses are shown in Fig. 5. there was 35% amino acid identity between the 3Dpol and the RdRp of other picornaviruses and 35% amino acid identity between the 2C of CPDV and the helicases of other picornaviruses. the relative luciferase activities of 5′ IRES and IGR IRES were 2.5-fold (P 0.005) and 2.9-fold (P 0.005) higher than that of RF-negative control. however, upon transfection of DNA constructs into 293T cells, the relative luciferase activities of 5′ IRES and IGR-IRES were greatly reduced and were comparable to the amount of activity in the RF-negative control. a total of 1,472 nasal, fecal, urine, and blood samples from 368 dogs were obtained from various locations in HKSAR. the sequences from the positive specimens fell into two distinct clusters, suggesting the presence of two novel picornavirus-like viruses. no cytopathic effect was observed by RT-PCR in any cell lines inoculated with the samples that were positive for CPDV. no signs of illness such as paralysis were observed in suckling mice within 14 days after inoculation. a putative GNRA loop is present in domain IV of the two IRESs of CPDV. the GNRA loops in the two IRESs have predicted structures that differ from the GNRA loop in other type 1 IRESs. the cloverleaf structure immediately upstream from all picornavirus type I IRESs was not identified in the N, no (absent); Y, presence of L and L is protease; Y/N, presence of L but the 2A of CPDV does not possess the characteristic catalytic amino acid residues with chymotrypsin-like proteolytic activity. it also does not possess any homology to other known viral or cellular proteins. 2C of CPDV possesses the DDLXQ motif for putative helicase activity (15) 3Dpol of CPDV contains conserved KDE[LI]R, YGDD, and FLKR motifs. the GG[LMN]PSG motif is replaced by the GAMPSG motif in CPDV. average evolutionary divergence of the coding regions in CPDV ranged from 0% to 8.1% for amino acid differences and 6.3% to 12.3% for nucleotide differences. the relative luciferase activities of bicistronic vector containing 5′ IRES and the IGR IRES of CPDV were 22.6-fold (P 0.005) and 4.5-fold (P 0.01) higher than that of RF-negative control, respectively. there was no evidence that this increase was due to splicosomal activity, since the relative luciferase activities of 5′ IRES and IGR IRES were 2.5-fold (P 0.005) and luciferase activities of cells transfected with pGL3E/5′ IRES and pGL3E/IGR IRES were comparable to that of the negative control. the luciferase activity of cells transfected with the positive control was 6-fold higher than that of negative control. CPDV is more related to other picornaviruses than to members of other families of viruses. phylogenetically, CPDV is more related to other picornaviruses than to members of other families of viruses. the presence of two IRES elements is genuine instead being due to artifacts. two IRES elements were observed in all three sequenced strains of CPDV. both CPDV IRESs are functional and could promote translation of structural and nonstructural polyprotein precursors from the genomic mRNA. CPDV could represent a missing link between dicistroviruses and picornaviruses. s of dicistroviruses possess two functional IRES elements, one at the 5′ UTR upstream from P2 and the other upstream from VP4. the genomes of picornaviruses possess only one IRES element at the 5′ UTR upstream from VP4. however, multiple steps of translocation and IRES deletion should be required for dicistroviruses to evolve to become picornaviruses.
